Award.AwardTitle: Cultural Dynamics and Overlapping Interaction Spheres in the Marmara Lake Basin, Western Turkey

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With National Science Foundation support, Dr. Christopher H. Roosevelt and Dr. Christina Luke will lead a three-year interdisciplinary research project exploring the cultural dynamics of social and political groups active in western Turkey during the Middle and Late Bronze Ages of the second millennium BCE. The project focuses on the Marmara Lake Basin of the middle Gediz River valley, a strategic gateway linking Aegean and central Anatolian spheres of interaction, to understand the local development and nature of centralized political authority in the context of dynamic and wider interaction spheres to east and west. Through integration of non-invasive surface survey, excavation, and sample and object analyses at a network of recently discovered citadels and other sites in the study area, the project investigates political alliances and economic relationships during a time in which Minoan and Mycenaean polities thrived in the Aegean and the Hittites of central Anatolia grew from a local kingdom to a vast territorial empire. The largest and most complex site of the local network was Kaymakçý, and it was likely both the local capital as well as that of an independent kingdom and later Hittite vassal known as the Seha River Land. The 8.6 ha citadel dates to the second millennium BCE, during which time parts of it were burned at least once, and after which time it appears to have been abandoned forever, leaving well-preserved Bronze Age remains on the surface.

These fundamental political and social processes are still at work in the Near East today and this archaeological project provides an excellent example to examine how they interact over an extended time period.

The proposed work will integrate geophysical and soil-chemistry surveys, excavation, ceramic and stone material studies, and botanical, faunal, and other subsistence and environmental sample analyses to address spatial organization, subsistence practices, and modes of material production for understanding the dynamics of social complexity in areas of overlapping interaction spheres. Furthermore, this research in the middle Gediz River valley will complement ongoing work elsewhere in Bronze Age Anatolia. While the valley has always been acknowledged as an important, connective corridor between the Aegean and central Anatolia, it has remained a major gap in archaeological and geo-political understandings of Minoan, Mycenaean, local Anatolian, and Hittite interactions in western Anatolia. The project plans to fill this gap with the first new excavation project in the region since the 1950s.

The broader impacts of the project include contributions to archaeological understandings of relationships between local communities, interregional interaction spheres, the spatial development of emergent political authorities, and the organizational characteristics of their subsistence management and material production activities. Additionally, the project will provide fieldwork opportunities and research topics for both American and foreign (especially Turkish) students. The educational impact of the project is of particular importance for contributing to archaeological heritage management in Turkey. With an American-Turkish team at both senior-researcher and student levels, and in cooperation with local representatives of the Turkish Ministry of Culture and Tourism, the project will foment international collaboration in promoting global, interdisciplinary, scientific, and "best practice" anthropological approaches to the rich field that is the archaeology of Anatolia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Support from the National Science Foundation allowed this project to explore the development, nature, and interactions of ancient communities located at the juncture of larger and better-known societies. Research under the Kaymakç? Archaeological Project in 2014–2017 was focused on Kaymakç?, a recently discovered citadel in western Turkey dating to the Middle and Late Bronze Ages (around 2000–1200 BCE), the extent and complexity of which was first identified during the Central Lydia Archaeological Survey (CLAS). A primary aim of this project was to understand Kaymakç?’s position within both local networks of the Marmara Lake Basin and regional networks stretching from the Aegean to central Turkey and the eastern Mediterranean. Methods included non- or minimally invasive geophysical and sediment geochemistry surveys, targeted excavations, and a variety of material and environmental analyses aiming to shed light on how Kaymakç? was organized internally and how its people sustained their daily lives and interacted with others near and far to supplement local products, including both foodstuffs and socially important objects (such as knives) and materials (such as metals). In addition to fulfilling its primary research goals, the project provided fieldwork opportunities and training for numerous American, Turkish, and other foreign students, laying the foundations for continued best practices in archaeological fieldwork.

Discovered in 2001, Kaymakç? offers a needed investigative window into society in second-millennium BCE western Turkey. Located in what is currently thought to be the core of the Seha River Land, an inland territory ruled by indigenous kings named in Hittite texts, Kaymakç? sat at a strategic point between Late Bronze Age world powers: the Hittites and Mycenaeans. Until now, we knew almost nothing of the people of Kaymakç? and their traditions. Geophysical results reveal a plan of settlement more similar to sites in western Turkey than to those in the Aegean or central Turkey. Excavations show that architectural techniques, too, are based on local traditions. Excavated materials confirm the basic timeline of the site – initial settlement around 2000 and abandonment around 1200 BCE, according to radiocarbon dates and diagnostic materials – and also reveal connections to communities in neighboring areas. Patterns of agriculture and animal husbandry show similarities to practices in both the Aegean and central Turkey, just as they highlight the dominance of local traditions. Decorative ornaments, tools, and other items, too, point to connections to the broader eastern Mediterranean world, but the material traditions of Kaymakç? reflect primarily local practices, including ceramic manufacture and textile production. All in all, the strength of local traditions at Kaymakç? must have enabled its community to interact with the broader eastern Mediterranean world, despite the inland locale of the site.

Over the course of four field seasons the project provided participants multiple opportunities for training and professional development in a variety of areas. Students learned to employ geophysical techniques to identify buried archaeological remains such as streets, houses, fortification walls, and more. Excavation opportunities resulted in the development of a cutting edge digital and 3D recording system in which all were trained. Additionally, students were trained to use and develop complex databases to manage and analyze textual, visual, and geospatial data; to identify and analyze ceramic, stone, and metal objects; to recover, identify, and analyze ancient environmental archaeological remains, including plant seeds and animal bones; and to recover and remove artifacts from archaeological contexts and to apply chemical treatments to stabilize them in conservation laboratory settings. In this way, the project not only fulfilled its scientific goals but also succeeded in training numerous American, Turkish, and other students in best practices of archaeological fieldwork and analysis, applicable in the US, Turkey, and elsewhere throughout the world.
